 Long term must be defined. If one looks at futurist projections, continent affiliation, the world is probably 25-50-years away from exhausting natural resources and low cost labor as a global trade format. My chronological age places me a position to where I look at 20-years as 'long-term'. 
 
 When I look at the next 20-years, what attracts my attention is China. Their 10-year plans, the only substantial nation I'm aware of with the ability to enforce that degree of planning, intends to raise their per-capita income from a current $1k to $10k (present net value) by 2021. They're running an average 8% of real GDP growth, without national debt and positive trade balance, which makes that goal achievable. So I look at that per-capita income as a benchmark. 
 
 Europe's EU is moving towards combining low labor cost nations with mature, high social cost nations, which, if they move fast enough and get most all of that continent's nations involved, will allow that affiliation to service niche markets, mostly middle/higher-end, but eventually lower the per-capita income of that affiliation to a level that will move closer to Asian (China) standards.

America holding most resource assets and the US as the largest consumer of resources (importer and debtor), will eventually reduce standards of living in the US until S. America's resources are utilized to evenly distribute that continent's per-capita income levels.

Trade is still the measure of national, or affilated wealth. That means value added exports move wealth from one entity to another. As usual, haves will dictate terms to have-nots.
